Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Acoustic Wave Glider
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Acoustic Wave Glider manufactured by Liquid Robotics, is a mobile, unmanned, quiet, ocean surface vehicle for the study of marine soundscapes and detection of acoustically tagged marine animals. The glider is powered by batteries recharged by solar photovoltaic panels and propelled by wave action, so that long unmanned missions can be achieved at very low cost. The glider can travel along programmed transects for months-long deployments collecting meteorological and ocean data and recording and identifying species that make sounds in the ocean soundscape, including both the natural (geophony and biophony) and anthropogenic (anthropophony) sounds. Some of the species that can be studied with the acoustic sensors on this glider include the endangered Atlantic sturgeon, red drum, striped bass, groupers, bluefin tuna, sharks, endangered right whales and bottlenose dolphins. The instrument package on the glider will allow multiple and simultaneous measurements of the ocean environment (waves using a Datawell MOSE-G1000 wave sensor; currents using a Teledyne RDI Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler; temperature, salinity, depth and dissolved oxygen using a Sea-Bird CTD+DO sensor; and turbidity and phytoplankton abundance using a Turner C-3 pumped fluorometer) and near-surface weather (air temperature, rainfall, wind speed using an Airmar 200WX Weather Station) during missions. An acoustic tag receiver (Vemco VR2C sensor) will be used to detect and track acoustically tagged animals, and a recording hydrophone and analysis system (Decimus PAMBuoy sensor) will record sounds produced by marine animals and classify them.

The glider will be used to monitor areas for the presence of sound-producing animals, to avoid noise and other impacts to threatened species in shipping and transportation corridors, to identify and protect fishing areas, and to assess impacts to areas proposed for wave and wind energy development, sand mining areas, and oil and gas leases. Data reports will be relayed from all the glider sensors to land-based computers via satellite and mobile phone modems in near-real-time for analysis, mapping and archival. Our overarching objective with the Acoustic Wave Glider is to document ocean habitats and biologic communities in continental shelf and slope waters to determine static communities (e.g., reefs) and migratory pathways of highly mobile species (e.g., fishes, marine mammals, sea turtles). Secondary objectives include providing data to oceanographers on environmental conditions during normal conditions and storm events to enhance storm prediction models. Storms and rainfall events can be analyzed for their impacts on ocean communities through acoustic analysis of organism responses. Storm events often cannot be sampled by vessels due to danger to life and equipment, but wave gliders are specifically designed to survive and report ambient ocean conditions, even during storm sea states and hurricanes. The glider will be featured at public displays of research at the NC aquariums, including static displays and interactive touch screens of glider tracks are planned. Scientific forums, seminars, and other public events will be scheduled, and glider users will be encouraged to write public interest articles about mission results for news media and magazines. The results of studies based data collected with the glider will be presented at scientific meetings and published in peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Remote observations of marine animal behavior have one distinct advantage over direct observations: the observer is not present to disturb the animals. There are no vessel noises, no diver's bubbles, no people present that could alter the behavior of the animals being observed. We wanted to obtain an autonomous vehicle (Liquid Robotics SV2 wave Glider equipped with hydrophones and acoustic tag detectors) that could be used to study the migratory behavior of fishes and whales remotely. With that objective, we have acquired under the NSF MRI program Blackbeard, the Acoustic Wave Glider (AWG), to conduct affordable, long-term monitoring of marine animals and coastal ocean acoustic environment.

The acoustic wave glider has several instrument sensors including 1) Decimus (SAIL, Saint Andrews Instrumentation Laboratory), a towed passive acoustic system; 2) Turner C3 fluorometer for recording the levels of phytoplankton chlorophyll, ocean color, and turbidity; 3) Teledyne Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) for measuring water currents under the wave glider float at depth strata top to bottom; 4) Sea Bird GPCTD conductivity and density meter with oxygen sensor, for measuring water temperatures, salinity levels, and dissolved oxygen levels for measuring the fish habitat use; 5) Vemco VR2C acoustic receiver and communication meter for detecting acoustically tagged fishes; 6) Datawell MOSE wave sensor for measuring wave heights and periods; and 7) Air Mar Weather station for measuring air temperature, humidity, and wind speeds.  We used the Wave Glider Management System software (WGMS), and Iridium satellite communications to send commands to and receive data from the wave glider while at sea.  In sea trials, the AWG followed all commands and was able to navigate a course of pre-programmed waypoints at a speed of 1-2 knots.

We deployed the AWG in a series of six sea trials with the Decimus and various sensors turned on and used remote commands to navigate.

Sea trial 1 was the inaugural deployment of the AWG and only the most basic meteorological, CTD, fluorometry, and wave height measurements were made. 

In Sea Trial 2, a Vemco V16 acoustic transmitter suspended at two depths (6.1 m and 12.2 m) in the water column for range testing of the VR2C mounted on the AWG submarine. We detected the Vemco V16 tag within a 500 m range. 

The AWG was sent along a course to record the wild soniferous animals in Sea Trials 3, 5 and 6.  Many fish (weakfish Cynoscion regalis and spotted seatrout Cynoscion nebulosus, striped cusk eels, Ophidion marginatum, sea robins Prionotus sp. and oyster toadfish Opsanus tau) and marine mammal sounds (bottlenose dolphins Tursiops truncatus and Humpback whales Megaptera novaeangliae) were recorded along these excursions. In Sea Trial 6, the Decimus (tuned to be neutrally buoyant in the towbody) was used to conduct a successful 10-d passive acoustic mission off the NC coast.  

The objective of Sea Trial 4 was to operate the AWG using the Vemco VR2C to detect acoustically tagged fish anticipated to be within the search area.  With a mini-grant to support the purchase of additional tags from the North Carolina Sea Grant program, 24 tagged southern flounder surgically implanted with Vemco V9 acoustic tags were released inshore in Bogue Sound, NC.   An extended search was conducted for these tagged fish with the wave glider offshore for 10 days after they were released. The Vemco VR2C did not detect any of these tagged southern flounder during the mission.  Using an inshore acoustic receiver array with collaborators at NC State University, we determined that most of these tagged fish did not leave the estuary or entered the search area after this mission was concluded. However, a sand tiger shark Carcharias taurus tagged with a V16 tag was detected by the AWG in Onslow Bay NC search area on 8 Dec 2015; this tag was placed in the female sand tiger in Delaware Bay 24 Aug 2012. 

Broader impacts:   We exhibited the Acoustic Wave Glider with a poster describing its capabilities at multiple venues.  We also provided a data sheet (available from the co-PIs and posted with our report to NSF) about the instrument which is being made available research user community.  We were exhibitors at the MARACOOS (Mid-Atlantic Regional Association Coastal Ocean Observing System) Annual Meeting (Annapolis, MD, in 2018).  We have also exhibited a poster on the wave glider and its capabilities at the Atlantic Estuarine Research Society (Rehoboth, DE in 2018), the Coastal and Estuarine Research Society (Portland, OR in 2015),  The American Fisheries Society (Tampa, FL in 2017), The International Conference on Fish Telemetry (Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada in 2015). Multiple graduate students and undergraduate students at East Carolina University were trained to be wave glider pilots, assisting with deployment, recovery, and analyses.  Finally, a video about the acoustic wave glider was made by UNC-TV and shown regularly on UNC public broadcasting system stations. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2019
Modified by: Joseph J Luczkovich

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Remote observations of marine animal behavior have one distinct advantage over direct observations: the observer is not present to disturb the animals. There are no vessel noises, no diver's bubbles, no people present that could alter the behavior of the animals being observed. We wanted to obtain an autonomous vehicle (Liquid Robotics SV2 wave Glider equipped with hydrophones and acoustic tag detectors) that could be used to study the migratory behavior of fishes and whales remotely. With that objective, we have acquired under the NSF MRI program Blackbeard, the Acoustic Wave Glider (AWG), to conduct affordable, long-term monitoring of marine animals and coastal ocean acoustic environment. The acoustic wave glider has several instrument sensors including 1) Decimus (SAIL, Saint Andrews Instrumentation Laboratory), a towed passive acoustic system; 2) Turner C3 fluorometer for recording the levels of phytoplankton chlorophyll, ocean color, and turbidity; 3) Teledyne Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) for measuring water currents under the wave glider float at depth strata top to bottom; 4) Sea Bird GPCTD conductivity and density meter with oxygen sensor, for measuring water temperatures, salinity levels, and dissolved oxygen levels for measuring the fish habitat use; 5) Vemco VR2C acoustic receiver and communication meter for detecting acoustically tagged fishes; 6) Datawell MOSE wave sensor for measuring wave heights and periods; and 7) Air Mar Weather station for measuring air temperature, humidity, and wind speeds. We used the Wave Glider Management System software (WGMS), and Iridium satellite communications to send commands to and receive data from the wave glider while at sea. In sea trials, the AWG followed all commands and was able to navigate a course of pre-programmed waypoints at a speed of 1-2 knots. We deployed the AWG in a series of six sea trials with the Decimus and various sensors turned on and used remote commands to navigate. Sea trial 1 was the inaugural deployment of the AWG and only the most basic meteorological, CTD, fluorometry, and wave height measurements were made. In Sea Trial 2, a Vemco V16 acoustic transmitter suspended at two depths (6.1 m and 12.2 m) in the water column for range testing of the VR2C mounted on the AWG submarine. We detected the Vemco V16 tag within a 500 m range. The AWG was sent along a course to record the wild soniferous animals in Sea Trials 3, 5 and 6. Many fish (weakfish Cynoscion regalis and spotted seatrout Cynoscion nebulosus, striped cusk eels, Ophidion marginatum, sea robins Prionotus sp. and oyster toadfish Opsanus tau) and marine mammal sounds (bottlenose dolphins Tursiops truncatus and Humpback whales Megaptera novaeangliae) were recorded along these excursions. In Sea Trial 6, the Decimus (tuned to be neutrally buoyant in the towbody) was used to conduct a successful 10-d passive acoustic mission off the NC coast. The objective of Sea Trial 4 was to operate the AWG using the Vemco VR2C to detect acoustically tagged fish anticipated to be within the search area. With a mini-grant to support the purchase of additional tags from the North Carolina Sea Grant program, 24 tagged southern flounder surgically implanted with Vemco V9 acoustic tags were released inshore in Bogue Sound, NC. An extended search was conducted for these tagged fish with the wave glider offshore for 10 days after they were released. The Vemco VR2C did not detect any of these tagged southern flounder during the mission. Using an inshore acoustic receiver array with collaborators at NC State University, we determined that most of these tagged fish did not leave the estuary or entered the search area after this mission was concluded. However, a sand tiger shark Carcharias taurus tagged with a V16 tag was detected by the AWG in Onslow Bay NC search area on 8 Dec 2015; this tag was placed in the female sand tiger in Delaware Bay 24 Aug 2012. Broader impacts: We exhibited the Acoustic Wave Glider with a poster describing its capabilities at multiple venues. We also provided a data sheet (available from the co-PIs and posted with our report to NSF) about the instrument which is being made available research user community. We were exhibitors at the MARACOOS (Mid-Atlantic Regional Association Coastal Ocean Observing System) Annual Meeting (Annapolis, MD, in 2018). We have also exhibited a poster on the wave glider and its capabilities at the Atlantic Estuarine Research Society (Rehoboth, DE in 2018), the Coastal and Estuarine Research Society (Portland, OR in 2015), The American Fisheries Society (Tampa, FL in 2017), The International Conference on Fish Telemetry (Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada in 2015). Multiple graduate students and undergraduate students at East Carolina University were trained to be wave glider pilots, assisting with deployment, recovery, and analyses. Finally, a video about the acoustic wave glider was made by UNC-TV and shown regularly on UNC public broadcasting system stations. Last Modified: 01/02/2019 Submitted by: Joseph J Luczkovich
